Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Databases for Many Majors: Customizable Visualizations to Improve STEM Learning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Databases are important in many disciplines for the storage and retrieval of information. However, database courses for undergraduates are typically only available as an upper-level elective course for computer science or business majors. This project builds on the successes of an earlier research project that introduced database concepts to students in many majors through animations using a visual and dynamic presentation with images and color. Visualization is an effective technique for instruction because it engages student interest and enhances their learning. In the earlier project, two animations were developed: one to introduce what databases are and a second to introduce how to retrieve the information stored in a database by asking questions, called queries. The goal for this project is for educators in diverse academic disciplines to incorporate the animations in their existing courses. To support this goal, the animations are customizable to different examples for various majors. Another goal is to develop an additional animations on how to organize data for storage in a database using visual diagrams. An enhancement to all animations is planned to provide a built-in quizzing mechanism so that the student can receive immediate feedback on what they are learning. The quizzes encourage student to learn and review the animation and do not to provide a grade to an instructor. Another goal of the project is to develop visual tools to assist instructors with the customization of the animation example to their discipline. As part of this project, the animations will be customized to additional STEM domains, specifically statistics, forensics, and ecology.

This research is expected to provide valuable contributions for improving STEM learning by providing customizable animations with self-assessment that introduce students from many majors to various database concepts. Another significant contribution is the investigation of a customizable self-assessment framework to incorporate within it the extensible animations for these database concepts. This self-evaluation is a necessary component for providing formative feedback to a student progressing thru these database concepts using the animations to improve their comprehension. Finally, the ability to customize the animations and the assessment questions is an important component of the research. This customization process uses XML technologies within the development environment, thus developing visual tools to assist in the customization of the animations for other disciplines.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Databases are important in many disciplines for the storage and retrieval of information. However, database courses are typically only available as an elective for computer science undergraduates at the upper level.This project builds on the successes of an earlier project in using the pedagogical tool of visualization for introducing database concepts to diverse majors. The earlier project developed two computer visualizations with color and images in a dynamic presentation. The first visualization, named IntroDB, introduces relational databases and how they differ from spreadsheets. QueryDB, the second visualization, covers how to ask questions of a database, and specifically presents the SQL industry standard query language. In addition, the framework for the visualizations incorporated a customization feature, where the data example and supporting text of the visualization could be changed by instructors to the domain of the course that they were teaching to introduce databases in context of their discipline. The first project included customizations for Geographic Information Systems and Computational Molecular Biology.

The goal of the current project is to build on the successes of the first by developing another visualization on how to design a relational database as well as establishing customizations in additional domains for STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics) disciplines. Another objective for this grant included the addition of a formative self-assessment feature in which students can assess themselves on their understanding of the concepts presented by the visualization, which would consist of twenty multiple-choice and true/false questions that were also customizable based on the visualization's example. To support the customization of the visualizations by instructors in other disciplines, a tool was proposed to provide interactive guidance on the data example so that it met the requirements for further customization in the suite of visualizations. 

All of these planned objectives were met. The DesignDB visualization introduces how to graphically represent the concepts and the relationships between these concepts using Entity Relationship Diagrams, which can then be mapped to a collection of tables in a relational database. A formative self-assessment feature, called a checkpoint, was added to all three visualizations, and students indicated that the checkpoints were very important for understanding the concepts presented by the visualization. A CreateDB tool, with a friendly, graphical interface similar to that of the visualizations, was developed to assist instructors in the customization process, resulting in additional STEM customizations in Astronomy, Environmental Science, Forensic Science, Neuroinformatics, and Statistics.

There were two additional aims that were introduced as the project developed. The first aim was the use of tools and techniques to improve the accessibility of the visualizations for those with color deficient vision, known as color blindness, which is the inability or the decreased abilty to discern color difference. The visualizations were improved by providing necessary contrast and using additional cues, instead of just color, to get the learner's attention. Another added objective was the implementation of the visualizations to a different programming language since the initial implementations of the visualizations would not be supported in Web browsers after 2020. 

The Databases for Many Majors project has had a broad impact through the use of the visualizations at multiple institutions with seven different STEM customizations. The research has been broadly disseminated by the project leaders as well as by the customizers within their disciplines.  Since databases are ubiquitous in our society, understanding database technology has the potential to improve students' job prospects, to support data aspects of interdisciplinary research, and to provide the skills needed to solve data-centric problems across many disciplines.
